channel.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
channel.description: So recently I’ve been trying to make my next song, but I can’t seem to put one together. Every time I get close to finishing a song, I feel like it’s not good enough, I could have made it better to I delete the whole project. It’s not a lack of inspiration: I have plenty of ideas that are in the form of 4 bar loops. But the problem is, when I work on a project for a while, it just isn’t good enough to be released and ends up in the trash. Does anybody have any suggestions on how to fix this?

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
I’m a fan of the idea of ‘donating’ unused snippets to the Auxy community domain. As you say, better that an idea gets a real chance of being developed, than sitting unused and unloved.

#SetIdeasFree

 
(I was going to do a major clearance, posting 20-30 undeveloped ideas here, but decided against it. I’ll be looking for a creative/writing partner this year, and they might hear them and have a clearer idea of how they could be developed.)

Read full topic
item.source: A bad case of the perfectionisms

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: NotMiles
item.description:
If I make a song that doesn’t really get off the ground I delete it (I keep the half-finished ones). The half-finished ones that I keep can turn into something in another song. (ie: Pastel City, Foggy)

Read full topic

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: KDS_Official
item.description:
And a melody, that’s what makes you remember the song, the melody is basically the most important thing, the best melodies are the simplest but also the catchiest… Probably why it takes me a week to think of one then I go to write it then it disappears

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Just post the link to the project and let others take a crack at it. Could either turn into a collab or you just get to hear someone else’s spin on something you started. Both are really cool

item.source: A bad case of the perfectionisms

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
I don’t think there is anything wrong with your approach.

A few years ago I decided that if I couldn’t get a track to ~90% in a few hours I would simply delete it.
It was the best decision I’ve ever made.

You can’t polish a turd. (but you could dip it in glitter and call it future bass).

Read full topic
item.source: A bad case of the perfectionisms

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
+ @Pinewoodog

If you believe there’s potential in those unfinished/unreleased tracks, then consider reaching out to make them a collab.

While you might be stuck trying to unlock the full potential of the idea, a collaborator might be able spot it more easily, and unlock it and shape it with you.

Read full topic
item.source: A bad case of the perfectionisms

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: MrSerpent
item.description:
That’s some pretty nice philosophy there. Definitely something to consider.

Also…you know…Auxy May or may not take up 20 gigs of space on my phone

Read full topic
item.source: A bad case of the perfectionisms

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Fwiw…

https://blog.landr.com/5-signs-perfectionism/

 
Additionally, I’m going to say something a little controversial…

Sometimes, some… times… deleting something you’ve created, but are stuck on, can actually be the best thing to do - because the act of deleting something can flush away all the creative angst that might be polluting other creative endeavours, allowing you to genuinely start something fresh, free from legacy thinking, with a new energy.

Read full topic
item.source: A bad case of the perfectionisms

True, it feels like a lot after a while. When you keep on making new chords, baselines, and melodies, you kinda stick in that loop until something good gets your attention.

item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Not saying that you don’t have OCD, just that it’s probably not causing your write-to-release ratio, because 1:15 probably isn’t that unusual.

item.title: A bad case of the perfectionisms
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Little_Baby:

I have extreme OCD, (Diagnosed) so I do the same. I post about 1 out of every 15 songs I make, cause of it,

I’m not sure that’s really the OCD. Many pro musicians probably have a similar write-to-release ratio, especially in the early years.
